paper.title: Phase-curve Evidence for an Atmosphere on TRAPPIST-1 b

core_question: Does the Earth-sized, tidally locked exoplanet TRAPPIST-1 b retain any atmosphere under the strong stellar irradiation from its M dwarf host star?

datasets_or_cohorts.label: Observed System
datasets_or_cohorts.description: The actual measurement data from JWST MIRI low-resolution spectroscopy capturing the thermal emission across the orbital phase of the exoplanet TRAPPIST-1 b.

datasets_or_cohorts.label: Bare-Rock Null Scenario
datasets_or_cohorts.description: A computational model of the planet assuming a completely airless, bare-rock surface with minimal heat redistribution, used as the baseline for comparison.

datasets_or_cohorts.label: CO2-rich Atmosphere Model
datasets_or_cohorts.description: Atmosphere retrieval model family with an assumed composition rich in carbon dioxide, predicting significant greenhouse gas absorption and heat transport.

datasets_or_cohorts.label: O2-rich Atmosphere Model
datasets_or_cohorts.description: Atmosphere retrieval model family assuming an oxidized composition, used to test alternative atmospheric chemistry scenarios and constraints.

major_limitations: This is a single-planet study and does not establish atmospheric prevalence across all M-dwarf rocky planets.
Retrieval assumptions (circulation, opacity priors, cloud treatment) affect quantitative posteriors.
Stellar variability and instrument systematics can bias weak spectral features.
Night-side constraints are weaker than day-side constraints in the current dataset.
